title: Firefox crashes when opening / closing tab (etc.)

title: Firefox acting weirdly on my computer. Loses tabs, opens new windows with the tabs, does not completely close
content:
Hi I replaced chrome with firefox last 2 days but I am having a host of problems since then I only use ublock origin as addon. This one I always used on chrome too OK so I have checked "open previous windows and tabs" but it is not respected. I open firefox, it's blank I look into the little icon to the top left and see a list of tabs that are split between a window 1 (current) and another window.

So, it informs me that magically I have more than 1 window firefox open I am not aware of.

Next, closing firefox, doesn't actually close it. I mean the usual x, alt-f4 In the task manager I still see firefox; some 8-12 processes. So this could mean that when I hit firefox shortcut thinking I have no firefox open and waiting to come back to my tabs, I get a blank firefox.

Next, wishing to perform an uninstall, I ...can't. It says firefox is running, it must first be ended(!) and if I want instead a cleanup

Next, some weirder things. With firefox open, opening spotify web in a new tab triggered the opening of a new firefox window with tabs I deemed lost.

I only use a single profile, that addon and all happens on a Windows 10 x64 machine with i5, 16GB RAM and NVME storage on which the single most recent modification was the replacement of chrome with firefox.
creator: woof

title: Hi, Firefox wont start up under W7 destkop.
content:
Hi, Firefox wont start up under W7 desktop.

Installed older version but keep getting error message "Firefox is already running, but not responding'. The old Firefox process must be closed to open a new window."

Processes Firefox.ex *32 appear in taskmanager after attempt to start Firefox. Killing these processes and then trying to start up Firefox results again in this message and having the processes Firefox.ex *32 appear in taskmanager again.

What else to check or to do?

Bye Arwin

title: Reader view Read aloud
content:
Hi there

I use the read aloud version quite often to help me retain what i'm reading, but the problem is the control of the reader is quite clunky when i have to pause or go back a paragraph. Is it possible to add a pause, play, fastforward and rewind button to the corner of the screen? being able to manage speed without having to restart from the begining of the page would also be very helpful. Is there an add on or setting where i can do this?

title: Can't change the suggestions in non-password/address bar fields
content:
There's one specific field I fill in very often and for some reason Firefox is really keen on suggesting me two searches that I looked up more than a couple months ago, on a totally different site. I can't even remove these suggestions or add new ones. When I used Vivaldi, it'd learn what I insert (even if it'd end up suggesting tens and tens of options), while Firefox doesn't learn at all.

For sake of an example, let's say that the word I use every day in this field is XYZ. Not even once was it suggested to me, I've only ever gotten the two in the screenshot below instead. And I can't remove them using the Delete key as some other article suggested.

Speaking of which, I just noticed the same thing happen to the subject line in this form üôÉ

title: Using policies.json to manage individual profiles on linux
content:
I'm having trouble using the policies.json file to manage individual profiles on Linux. I've come across sources that suggest placing the distribution/policies.json file in the profile folder should work, but I can't seem to get it to function as expected.

My use case is to create a separate profile that can only connect to localhost.

I have a few questions:

  • Is there a specific way to use policies.json for managing individual profiles on Linux? If so, what is the correct method?
  • Can the location where Firefox looks for the policies.json file be overwritten for a new process? If yes, how can this be achieved?

title: ads telemetry
content: For over a decade, I trusted Firefox implicitly, believing in your unwavering commitment to user privacy and respect. Today, that trust was shattered when I opened my browser to find ads plastered across my homepage. This isn't just an annoyance; it's a betrayal of the very principles that drew me to your software. You've reduced yourselves to the same level as the data-hungry corporations you once stood against. It's not just disappointing‚Äîit's despicable. I will not stand by and accept this violation. Consider this my farewell, as I cannot in good conscience continue to use a product that so blatantly disregards its users. You've lost more than just a customer; you've lost the respect and loyalty of someone who once championed your cause.
creator: pedrobackard
